urn:contentItem:5VF3-17R1-JB5M-W3G8-00000-00Is India Digitally Prepared for International Trade?2019-02-02T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:03:11ZLexisNexisIs India Digitally Prepared for International Trade?Rashmi Banga

Rashmi Banga (rashmi.banga@unctad.org) is Senior Economic Affairs Officer, Unit on Economic Cooperation and Integration among Developing Countries, Division on Globalization and Development Strategies, United Nations Conference on Trade and Development.

India's digital infrastructure and the value added by digital services to its exports are analysed in order to assess its digital preparedness in the context of international trade. The results show that India lags behind many developing and developed countries in this area. In order to boost India's trade competitiveness in the digital era, a Digitally-Informed Foreign Trade Policy is advocated that would aim to improve India's digital infrastructure for trade, enhance the digital content in its exports, build digital skills in tradeable sectors, promote the use of digital technologies in manufacturing exports, and use big data analytics to inform foreign trade policy.



An earlier version of the paper "Is India Digitally Prepared for International Trade?" was uploaded as a discussion paper of Research and Information System for Developing Countries in December 2018.

With the onset of the fourth industrial revolution, also called Industry 4.0, many developing countries, including India, are facing new opportunities and challenges in international trade. Increasing digitalisation can greatly impact the trade competitiveness of the countries, benefiting those who are able to increase the digital content of their production and exports while adversely impacting countries that are unable to catch up in the digital race. To digitally prepare itself, India has initiated some concrete programmes like Digital India, which aims to transform India into a digitally empowered society and a knowledge economy. As stated on its official website, it aims to provide citizens "with Digital Infrastructure as a Utility; Governance and Services on Demand; and Digital Empowerment." The government has initiated many sub-programmes under Digital India, including the Aadhaar identity platform, an agri-market app, e-panchayat, and MyGov. The government has also initiated a working group to design a national policy for e-commerce. In this context, the main objective of this article is to examine India's digital preparedness in the context of international trade by comparing the country's digital infrastructure to other developing and developed countries, along with various indicators of digital development. It will also attempt to estimate the extent of digital content in India's exports in different sectors-including its traditional export sectors-as compared to other countries. It also aims to offer a way forward through suggestions that aim to help increase India's trade competitiveness in the digital era.

Digitalisation can impact the global trade competitiveness of a country since it affects all the stages of a value chain, including pre-production, production, and post-production. It could lead to a large-scale reorganisation of existing global value chains (GVCs) and result in the emergence of new GVCs. Firms are using big data analytics to analyse consumer preferences, forecast demand, and customise products. Super platforms like Google, Amazon, Facebook, Apple, and Alibaba are providing two-sided and in some cases many-sided markets where producers and consumers can interact, enabling the platforms to collect more data and strengthen their capacity to reorganise international markets (Gurkaynak et al 2017; Rysman 2009). The network effect increases the gains of these platforms and enhances their global competitiveness, thereby allowing them to lock in their attractiveness, destroy competition, and emerge as powerful monopolies (Belleflamme and Peitz 2016).

Even though reining in the fast-growing super platforms and big tech firms is a challenge for developing countries, these platforms are also opening access to new markets and exposing domestic consumers to new products and producers through e-commerce. Further, digital technologies like robotics and 3D printing are increasingly being used in the production stage. This is creating opportunities for developing countries to upgrade their position in GVCs, as a higher amount of digital content can add value to their exports. However, it also heightens risk. If countries are unable to digitise their manufacturing, they face the prospect of losing global trade competitiveness, even in their traditional export sectors and within domestic markets.

While there is a vast quantity of literature on the various factors affecting trade, digitalisation is a relatively new factor and very few studies have empirically estimated its impact on trade, especially in India. The debate around the possible impact of digitalisation on international trade began in 1998 when the World Trade Organization (WTO) member nations decided on a moratorium on customs duties on electronic transmissions. The growing digitalisation of exportable products like software, music, e-books, and video games-which were earlier exported as physical products but are increasingly being delivered electronically-has prompted research on the implications of the moratorium. Surveys estimated that Zimbabwe experienced a significant tariff revenue loss by not imposing duties on digital products (Makoni et al 2013). Banga (2017) estimated the impact of a permanent zero duty regime on 38 products that are being increasingly digitalised and exported electronically. The study found that a permanent moratorium would lead to an increase in the import of digital products by developing countries and additional tariff revenue losses for many countries. India was found to be a net importer of these identified digitalised products in 2015.

It must be noted that digitalisation has proceeded very rapidly over the past few years and its impact on international trade goes beyond custom duties on electronic transmissions. In this scenario, like many other developing countries, India is also grappling to digitalise as fast as possible in order to retain its trade competitiveness. To assess whether India will be able to retain its competitiveness in the digital world, this article compares the country's existing digital infrastructure and its use of digital technologies with other developing and developed countries. Further, the article estimates the value added by digital services to the total exports and sector-specific exports of 43 countries.1 Digital services includes computer programming, consultancy and related activities, information services, and telecommunications. The analysis is based on national input-output tables derived from the world input-output tables taken from the World Input-Output Database and is undertaken at aggregate and sectoral levels using Leontief decomposition (in the R package). The article further suggests ways for India to increase its trade competitiveness in the digital era by designing a digitally informed foreign trade policy, which can help in increasing the digital content in India's exports and improve its global competitiveness.

The article first discusses the interrelated components of digital infrastructure and compares India's existing digital infrastructure with those of other developing and developed countries using various indicators. The subsequent section outlines the methodology of the article and presents the results of empirical estimates of the value added by digital services to India's total exports and compares it with other countries. The comparison is made over time for total exports as well as for exports at the sectoral level. This is followed by a discussion on the need for a digitally informed foreign trade policy in India and the importance of preserving policy space in trade and investment agreements, especially in the WTO.

Digital Infrastructure: India and the World

Digital infrastructure goes much beyond information and communications technology (ICT) and e-commerce. It can comprise three kinds of interrelated infrastructures: ICT infrastructure, cloud computing infrastructure, and data infrastructure, all of which are accompanied by the use of related digital skills and technologies. Figure 1 depicts the different layers of digital infrastructure.



Creating ICT infrastructure, which constitutes universally accessible and affordable internet access and connectivity, is the first step towards building digital infrastructure. This is complemented by ICT education and skills. The second step towards building digital infrastructure is to develop and use cloud computing infrastructure. Cloud computing involves soft infrastructure that can remotely provide computing services as a general utility to all internet users. These services can be further divided into three main categories: Infrastructure as a Service (IaaS), Software as a Service (SaaS) and Platform as a Service (PaaS). IaaS is a self-service model for managing remote data centre infrastructures, including networking services like firewalls or server spaces. SaaS eliminates the need to install applications on individual computers through web-based services such as Google Apps, Facebook, and Twitter. The PaaS model reduces the amount of coding required for developers to customise software. Users can create apps through software components that are made available by PaaS. By providing remote infrastructure, cloud computing has the potential to greatly reduce the need for hard infrastructure like storage disks and drastically reduce the cost of computing and using software in a country.

The most important component of digital infrastructure is data infrastructure, which has the ability to give rise to global monopolies and change the relative positions of countries in terms of their shares in global production, consumption, investments, and international trade. Data infrastructure consists of two parts: data and data intelligence. Many have termed data the "new oil" since it powers the digital economy in the same way as oil powers the industrial economy.2 Data is generated not just by the people who use the internet, but by almost every person who uses smart technologies like televisions, cars, phones, and fridges, since the Internet of Things (IoT) has made it possible to connect devices through sensors and collect data. Non-personal data is also generated by purchasing goods, seeking admission to schools, getting admitted in hospitals, using toll roads, and so on. Data intelligence combines several layers of data to form big data, which is then transformed into information through analysis. This information leads to knowledge that is converted into value. The value generated from big data is unique and forms the basis of Artificial Intelligence (AI), which helps create unique products and services that are more efficient and less costly to produce and consume.

Ownership of data and the capability of intelligently transforming data into highly-efficient products and services has led to the growth of big tech firms-also known as "superstar firms"-with monopolistic powers (Autor et al 2017). Economies of scale and network effects make it difficult for new firms to compete with these large monopolies. Google, Apple, Facebook, Amazon, Alibaba, Airbnb, and Uber are examples of such monopolies created by the digital economy. Data intelligence manifests itself in designing digital technologies like AI, robots, 3D printing, and e-commerce.

Comparing India's digital infrastructure with those of other developing and developed countries can provide an assessment of the relative position of India in the digital world.

ICT Infrastructure and Digital Skills

India has progressed fast in terms of building its ICT infrastructure. Internet users increased from 1.4 million in 1998 to 462 million in 2016, that is, from 0.1% of India's population to 36.5% of its population.3 Despite this rapid increase in the number of internet users and other initiatives of the Indian government, India lags behind many developing countries not only in terms of its ICT development index ranking-which is based on internet access, connectivity, and affordability-but also in most ICT development indicators. In fact, India is behind much smaller countries like Vietnam, Cambodia, Bangladesh, and Sri Lanka in many ICT development indicators.

Table 1 compares India to other countries in terms of some of the major ICT development indicators. India's ICT development index gives it a rank of 134 out of 176 countries. Apart from developed countries, most of Asia's developing nations such as Thailand, Indonesia, Philippines, Malaysia, Singapore, Vietnam, Cambodia, and Sri Lanka rank higher than India. India ranks lower than most of these countries in terms of fixed broadband subscription per 100 inhabitants, active mobile broadband subscription per 100 inhabitants, 3G coverage, percentage of households with internet access, and in terms of international internet bandwidth per internet user. Compared to China, India ranks lower in almost all indicators of ICT development. In fact, India does not meet the Asia-Pacific average for most ICT development indicators. Even within the BRICS (Brazil, Russia, India, China and South Africa) grouping, India has the lowest ICT development index ranking and lags behind in other ICT development indicators. Compared to the world average, India lags behind in terms of all ICT development indicators.



In terms of digital skills, India appears to be in a much stronger position. In 2014, according to the International Data Corporation (IDC), there were 21.03 million software developers in the world at the start of 2017. According to Evans Data Corporation, the United States (US) has 3.6 million developers compared to India's 2.75 million, which it estimates will rise to 5.2 million by the end of 2018, overtaking the US, which will have an estimated 4.5 million developers by then (Thibodeau 2013). Although India may surpass the US in terms of number of developers, according to HackerRank, in terms of quality of developers, China ranks number one while India ranks 31st in a list of 50 countries (Trikha 2016). The value of the global software products market stood at $413 billion in 2017, with an annual growth rate of 10.4%, while India's share was only 2% (Nasscom 2017; New Indian Express 2017).

Cloud Infrastructure

India is proactively promoting cloud infrastructure in the country. Digital India includes initiatives like DigiLocker, which is a cloud-based storage system for official documents. Further, e-governance, which provides real time information, and e-banking, which enables mobile banking services, are both initiatives that involve huge amounts of data and therefore, need cloud infrastructure. The public cloud market in India was worth $1.9 billion in 2017 and is expected to grow to $4.2 billion by 2020 (Gartner 2017). Several major global cloud providers, including Alibaba, Amazon, Google, and Microsoft have opened data centres in the country.

However, in spite of this fast growth in cloud computing, India's performance compares unfavourably with its global competitors. In metrics that are crucial to developing competitive cloud computing services such as internet bandwidth per Internet user-which measures total used capacity of international internet bandwidth in megabytes per second divided by total number of internet users-India ranks very low (116th out of 143 countries) (Table 2). Many South Asian countries like Bangladesh, Pakistan, and Sri Lanka rank higher than India while South East Asian countries like Malaysia, Indonesia, Philippines, Thailand, and Cambodia also rank higher than India. Within the BRICS countries, India ranks second-lowest after Brazil, Russia, and South Africa. India cannot be compared with developed countries like the US, UK, and Germany in this regard as they all rank within the top 50.



When it comes to the affordability of fixed broadband internet tariffs (monthly subscription charges for wired broadband internet in terms of purchasing power parity, measured in US dollars), India ranks quite high compared to other developing countries (36th out of 140) because of its well-regulated prices, although the difference in prices is not large. Other South Asian countries like Bangladesh, Sri Lanka, Nepal, and Pakistan all rank higher than India. However, many South East Asian countries have higher prices than India.

Internet speed is just as important as the price of internet use. According to Akamai, India ranks 89th out of 149 countries in terms of connection speeds, with an average speed of 6.5 megabytes per second (Table 2). India is also behind 100 countries, including most of South East Asia, in terms of secure internet services per million people.

Although India ranks low in the aforementioned indicators with respect to cloud infrastructure, the country has been projected as one of the top global destinations for cloud services. According to the National Association of Software and Services Companies (NASSCOM), the Indian saaS market, which was worth $407 million in 2016, is expected to triple in value by 2020. India's tech start-up ecosystem has been hailed as rising and shining, and competing with China for the third position globally, after the US and the UK (NASSCOM 2017). These trends are encouraging for India. However, other countries are developing their tech start-up ecosystems much faster, and according to the 2017 Global Start-up Ecosystem Report, which looks at 55 start-up ecosystems across 28 countries and ranks the top 20, Bengaluru (India) ranked 20th, dropping five places in a year.

Data Infrastructure

Some of the important components of data infrastructure include big data analytics, AI, robotics, 3D printing, and e-commerce. Comparing the progress made by India with other countries in these areas is difficult due to scant statistics. However, the available statistics do show that even in this area, India needs to catch up with other developing and developed countries.

Big data and artificial intelligence: In terms of big data analytics and AI, China has made rapid progress and is now catching up with the US. The global big data market grew from $7.6 billion in 2011 to $22.5 billion in 2015. In 2017, it grew to $35 billion and is expected to reach $56 billion in 2020 (Statista 2018). The big data market in China grew by 45% in 2016 to reach $2.5 billion. According to NASSCOM, India also has a growing big data analytics sector valued at around $2 billion. NASSCOM predicts that India's big data market will grow at a compound annual growth rate (CAGR) of 26% and will amount to 32% of global market in 2022. However, according to the Worldwide Semi-Annual Big Data and Analytics Spending Guide, published by IDC, the Asia Pacific big data market will reach $14.7 billion in 2018. China, at $5.5 billion, will have the biggest market, followed by Australia, Indonesia, Philippines and Thailand (Analytics Insight 2018).

While AI is still in its nascent stages in India, China has made it a national priority and is rapidly developing its AI industry. India's budget allocation for the Digital India programme stands at $477 million, while China is developing a technology park in Beijing worth $2.1 billion, which is greater than the total spending of the US on AI programmes in 2016 of about $1.2 billion (Xinhua 2018). China intends for its AI industry to generate $60 billion annual output by 2025 and become a $150 billion industry by 2030.

In 2017, the Association for the Advancement of Artificial Intelligence indicated a 13% growth in research output from China in the period 2012-17, as compared to a 6% decline in the US. Although comparative figures are not available for India, a study shows that India as a whole produces fewer machine learning papers than a single university in China (Aggarwal et al 2015). According to the Global AI Talent Report of 2018, India's pool of 386 AI researchers is the 10th largest. Among major economies, it has the lowest number of PhD-level AI researchers, trailing the US (9,010), the UK (1,861), Canada (1,154), France (797), Australia (657), Germany (626), Spain (606), Switzerland (441), and China (413).

Countries are rapidly increasing their investments in AI and India is also gearing up with a nationwide AI programme and focused funding for research and development (R&D) of AI. Under the nationwide AI programme, it is expected that new schemes, incentives, and industrial policies will be launched for start-ups and venture funds, but these will take time to fructify. With investments in AI increasing, there is also a growing demand for people with digital skills. While there is a large pool of information technology (IT) workers in India according to NASSCOM, almost 50% of the IT workforce will need to learn new technologies.

Robotics: One of the fastest-growing digital technologies is robotics. Since 2010, the demand for industrial robots has accelerated due to the increased use of automation and AI. According to the International Federation of Robotics (IFR), global robot sales grew at a CAGR of 12% between 2010 and 2016. India has also experienced a rise in its use of robots (Table 3). The number of delivered industrial robots increased by more than 200% in 2016 (2,627) as compared to 2010 (776). However, compared to developed countries and China, India seems to lag far behind. In 2016, five countries-China, South Korea, Japan, the US, and Germany-accounted for 74% of the total sales of robots. In 2016, China surpassed the US and Germany with 87,000 industrial robots. India's performance has been favourable compared to other developing countries and BRICS countries. In 2016, its operational stock surpassed those of most developing countries.



An important indicator of trade competitiveness of manufactured products in the future will be the use of robots in the manufacturing sector. Table 3 reports the use of robots in manufacturing in 2010 and 2016 for selected developed and developing countries. India's manufacturing sector had an operational stock of 11,237 in 2016, while countries like China, Germany, and the US had more than 1,00,000. Other developing countries, with the exception of Thailand, lagged behind India in the operational stock of robots used in their manufacturing sectors.

While this indicator appears to provide an important competitive edge to Indian manufacturing, it is important to take into consideration the relative size of the manufacturing sector. Thus, robot density-the number of multipurpose industrial robots per 10,000 persons employed in the manufacturing industry-becomes a useful metric. India has one of the lowest robot densities among the selected countries. The global average robot density is 74 robots per 10,000 employees in manufacturing sector. While China is close to the global average and has recorded the fastest growth in robot density (increasing from 25 in 2013 to 68 in 2016), India's robot density remains lower than Malaysia, Thailand, Indonesia, South Africa, and Brazil.

3D printing: Along with automation and robotics, additive manufacturing or 3D printing is progressing fast in the digitalised world. Although 3D printing was invented in the 1980s, it became widespread only after some key patents expired in 2009 and 2014. Between 2014 and 2017, the total number of desktop 3D printers sold nearly tripled, with a CAGR of 42% (Adams 2018). The IDC estimates global spending on 3D printing to be around $12 billion in 2018. India has also made progress in 3D printing although it is still at the initial stages of developing this market.

According to A T Kearney's 2017 3D Printing Index-which is based on 38 quantitative metrics in six dimensions using indicators such as a country's current 3D printing footprint, its share in global sales of 3D printers, and 3D printing patent applications-the leaders in this field with an index score between 4.1 and 7.5 are countries like the US, Germany, South Korea, Japan, the UK, Singapore, Canada, Sweden, and France (Smith IV et al 2017). With index scores between 2.7 and 4.0, the challengers are Australia, China, Italy, Malaysia, Taiwan, Spain, Russia, the Czech Republic, and Turkey. Countries with index scores between 0.9 and 2.6-including India with a score of 2.5-are seen as followers. In terms of 3D printing, India ranks 25th among 28 countries-below Indonesia, Malaysia, Vietnam, Brazil and South Africa.

E-commerce: Buying and selling goods and services on the internet is catching on fast. However, there is a need to distinguish between domestic e-commerce and cross-border e-commerce. According to UNCTAD (2018), using various country reports of ACATURE (2015), the e-products and electronically transmitted products market is estimated to be worth approximately $22.5 trillion. Of this, around $21 trillion is estimated to be domestic e-commerce-the buying and selling of e-products within the boundaries of countries. Cross-border e-commerce-international trade wherein e-products cross national boundaries-is estimated to be worth $1.6 trillion. According to NASSCOM, the Indian e-commerce market was worth $14 billion in 2015, up from $10.5 billion in 2014, and having grown at a CAGR of 30% since 2010. Despite this growth, India has a minuscule share-around 1%-of the global cross border e-commerce market, with 69% of it controlled by three countries: China (40%), the US, (20%), and the UK (9%) (UNCTAD 2018). They are followed by Japan (5%), Germany (4%), and France (4%). Thus, six countries control more than 85% of the cross-border e-commerce market.

The rise in cross-border consumer spending in India needs to be an issue of concern rather than celebration. According to a report by PayPal and Ipsos MORI, Indian shoppers spent more than $8.7 billion on cross-border e-commerce in 2016; an increase of 7% since 2015 (Paypers 2017). The report further predicted that Indian shoppers are likely to spend 85% more on global online marketplaces in 2018 (Ahluwalia 2017). The increase of imports into India via e-commerce needs urgent attention.

It is important to note that the rise of large international e-commerce platforms like Amazon and Alibaba has made it extremely difficult for national e-commerce platforms to compete, especially given the anti-competitive practices, such as predatory pricing, employed by international players. The recent acquisition of India's Flipkart by Walmart is an example of the consequences of the anti-competitive practices of the global giants, which follow predatory pricing and bear losses in certain countries in order to compete and wipe out local competition. On the back of its Indian unit's battle with Flipkart, Amazon's international losses amounted to over $3 billion (Variyar 2018).

Figure 2 depicts, over time, the profits of a few platforms as a percentage of their revenues. This ratio is as high as 50% for firms like Baidu, while the average profits to revenues ratio for the top 2000 Transnational Corporations for the period 2011-15 is 7%. This makes it possible for these digital platforms to compete with national platforms in identified countries using predatory pricing.



The profits of these international digital platforms are huge compared to India's e-commerce platforms, which are much smaller in size and mostly make losses or at best, minuscule profits (Abhudeen 2017). In 2015, Amazon's profits were $596 million while Alibaba recorded profits of $3.9 billion.

To compare India's preparedness in e-commerce with other countries, two indicators are used. According to UNCTAD's B2C E-commerce Index, which estimates a country's preparedness for e-commerce and is based on the processes involved in online shopping by consumers directly from sellers, in 2016, India ranked 90th. In the World Economic Forum's Networked Readiness Index, it ranked 91st out of a list of 140 countries, with countries like China, Malaysia, Thailand, Sri Lanka, Vietnam, and Kenya ranking higher than India.

To estimate the impact of digitalisation on trade competitiveness, value added by digital services (computer programming, consultancy and related activities, information service activities, and telecommunications) in total exports and sectoral exports is estimated for 43 countries, including India for the years 2007 and 2014. This indicates the changing trade competitiveness of countries which will depend primarily on the extent of the digital content added to their exports in the digital era.

Methodology

To estimate the extent of the increase in the contribution of digital services to total exports and sectoral exports, national input-output tables (derived from WIOD) for 43 countries for 2007 and 2014 are used. Further, using Leontief decomposition (in the R package), value added by digital services to total exports is estimated. Estimations are also carried out at a disaggregated sectoral level. The analyses are undertaken for all 43 countries for which national input-output tables are available in the database. These are mostly developed countries but BRIC nations, Indonesia, and Taiwan are also included.

Value Added by Digital Services to Total Exports

Using the above methodology, the estimated value added by digital services to the total exports of a few major economies in 2007 and 2014 has been calculated and presented in Table 4. The first column records the value added by digital services to total exports, while the second column excludes exports of digital services from the same. Although India ranks much lower than other countries in many indicators of digital preparedness, the value added by digital services to India's total exports compares favourably with many developing and developed countries.



In 2007, India ranked third in the world in terms of value added to exports by digital services in absolute terms, which amounted to $35.5 billion as compared to the US' $38.6 billion. In 2014, there was a 46% rise in the value added by digital services to India's total exports, which reached $51.8 billion, maintaining India's rank of third highest in the world. This may have lent a sense of confidence to the industry as well as policymakers with regards to India's competitiveness in the digital world. However, a closer examination of the extent of value added by digital services to exports, excluding exports of digital services themselves (exports of ICT and telecommunications services), paints a very different picture. As reported in Table 4, the value added by digital services to India's total exports in 2014-excluding exports of digital services-is only around $5.9 billion as compared to the $34.2 billion and China's $23.3 billion. This highlights the lopsided digitalisation of India's exports, which is focused mainly on exports of digital services-computer programming, consultancy and related activities, information service activities, and telecommunications.

Table 5 reports sector-wise estimates of value added by digital services to India's exports in 2014. The majority of the $51.8 billion in value added by digital services in 2014 was concentrated in just a few sectors. Two sectors-computer programming, consultancy and related activities, and information service activities, and telecommunications-accounted for 84.5% and 4% of the total value added by digital services. Among the other sectors, only two-textiles, wearing apparels, and leather products, and chemicals and chemical products-had a share equal to or greater than 1%.



In textiles, wearing apparels, and leather products, the value added by digital services to exports amounts to only 2.3%, while in the manufacture of computer, electronics, and optical products, value addition is highest at 10.1%, followed by printing and air transport. The above results show that India's digitalisation has been concentrated in very few sectors, while in countries like China and the US, digitalisation is experienced across many sectors.

Table 6 (p 60) compares sectoral shares of value added by digital services to the exports of India, China, and the US. The results show that while the value added by digital services in India is highly concentrated in the exports of digital services, in China and the US, value is added to exports in many sectors. The share of computer programming and related services and telecommunications is around 25% in China and 42% in the US, compared to India's 88%. Eighteen sectors out of 34 contribute more than 1% share in China compared to three sectors in India and 16 sectors in the US. In China, sectors which account for more than 3% of the total value added by digital services include manufacturing of computer, electronic, and optical products, manufacturing of electrical equipment, manufacturing of machinery and equipment, manufacturing of textiles, wearing apparels, and leather products, wholesale trade, and water transport. This indicates that in terms of adding digital content to its

exports, India lags far behind China and the US. India lags far behind China and the US in almost all sectors-except exports of digital services-in terms of digital content in exports.



Further, in absolute terms, India has very low digital content in its sectoral exports compared to China and the US. Figure 3 compares value added by digital services in exports of selected sectors in China, India, and the US. The only sector where the value added by digital services in India is higher than that of China is in exports of coke and petroleum products. This data highlights India's lack of digital preparedness in the context of international trade compared to some of its key competitors.



Need for a Digitally Informed Foreign Trade Policy

To remain competitive in global trade, India needs to boost the digital content in its exports, develop its digital infrastructure and skills, and increase the use of digital technologies in the export-oriented sectors of its economy. While many initiatives within the Digital India programme aim to accelerate India's digital transformation, and a national e-commerce policy is also being prepared, there is an urgent need for a much more holistic approach towards digitalisation in order to improve the digital content in India's exports. E-commerce development may help link exporters to digital platforms and give them access to global markets but if their exportable products have lower digital content, they will not be able to successfully compete in the global market in the digital era. Further, e-commerce platforms also allow international sellers to access India's domestic markets with more competitive products that have more digital content. This may lead to the erosion of domestic market shares of Indian producers. There is, therefore, an urgent need to develop a Digitally Informed Foreign Trade Policy (DIFTP) for India with the objective of increasing the digital content of India's exports and enhancing use of digital services, skills, and technologies in the trade sector, especially in traditional export sectors.

Setting up a DIFTP would involve building digital infrastructure for trade: enhancing the digital connectivity of traders, promoting digital skills in export sectors, developing data infrastructure for trade, fostering digital start-ups-especially in tradable sectors-encouraging the use of digital technologies and digital services in traditional export sectors, and promoting national digital platforms.

The Indian government has already initiated India Stack, a unique digital infrastructure project that allows governments, businesses, start-ups, and developers to utilise presence-less, paperless, and cashless service delivery. In 2009, the Unique Identification Authority of India (UIDAI) was set up to empower the citizens of India with a unique identity, Aadhaar, and a digital platform to authenticate users anytime anywhere. This was followed by the launch of the Aadhaar payments bridge and the Aadhaar-enabled payment system, which used the unique identity to electronically channelise government benefits and subsidies. In 2012, e-know your customer (eKYC) was launched, allowing businesses to perform customer verification digitally using biometric or mobile one-time password (OTP). This was followed by the launching of eSign by the Controller of Certifying Authorities in 2015, which allowed Aadhaar holders to digitally sign documents. This was accompanied by a national platform called DigiLocker, which allowed official documents and certificates to be issued and verified digitally, eliminating the need for physical documents. In 2016, the National Payments Corporation of India launched the Unified Payments Interface to revolutionise digital payments in India.

India's foreign trade policy needs to keep pace with these initiatives and incorporate them to boost the digitalisation of the country's international trade. These schemes, if used effectively to inform the foreign trade policy, can greatly improve India's trade competitiveness. For example, there is a need to redesign and digitalise India's farm subsidies, the current of implementation of which can be challenged in the WTO. These schemes can use the Aadhaar payments bridge as well as eKYC and eSign to protect farmers' agricultural revenues through alternative subsidy systems like the US's agricultural subsidies, which are direct payments. This would not only boost agricultural production, but also exports, by making farmers more attuned to digital payments and trade.

Digital Initiatives Needed

India's traditional export sectors also need to be injected with digital initiatives under DIFTP. First and foremost, there is a need to protect national digital platforms. Digital platforms are the backbone of global digital trade and are fast emerging as global monopolies which extract ever-increasing rents. Global digital platforms have the power to reorganise sectors and global trade. Google, Apple, Facebook, Amazon, and Alibaba, along with others like Uber and Airbnb, are rising global platforms which are wiping away competition due to their network effects and the associated power of data analytics. India's DIFTP needs to initiate national infant platform protection schemes. These platforms can incentivise domestic producers to export and provide access to new markets to existing exporters. The national e-commerce policy needs to be designed around this objective. Public-private partnerships could be encouraged to form national e-commerce platforms to boost exports and use the data analytics of engaged customers to forecast future demand, and changing tastes and preferences. Linking domestic producers to the national e-commerce platforms can be made a part of national trade promotion schemes. Chinese e-commerce platform policies can provide rich learnings for India. For example, a Chinese e-commerce platform called Kikuu, operates in six African countries, selling only Chinese goods.

Building digital infrastructure for trade is the key to building trade competitiveness in the digital era. While a lot of emphasis has been laid on building ICT infrastructure, there is a need to shift focus to building data infrastructure. Many developing countries have started developing their national data policies. For example, Rwanda has initiated a national data policy. Data needs to be stratified into different categories and classifications to identify data that can be made available publicly for big data analytics, data that needs to be analysed by the government before being shared with key stakeholders, and data that cannot be shared with foreign firms. Further, developing digital skills like designing using computer-aided design and building software must be prioritised, especially in traditional export sectors like textiles, clothing, and leather products. Many countries have initiated digital education in schools and universities, and are now offering courses on building digital skills. Special courses need to be initiated for training the workforce in trade sectors to use digital technologies and digital services.

The DIFTP should use big data analytics to inform trade policy and promote trade. While personal data is protected under the right to privacy in India, non-personal real-time data needs to be analysed by the government for trade trends, existing opportunities, and upcoming challenges for designing trade policies and for trade promotion. Trade policy in many countries is now informed by big data analytics. For example, companies such as Panjiva in the US employ intelligent feature extraction based on machine learning to aggregate and derive custom transaction information through analytics, which they use to provide decision-makers with actionable trade information, like how developing countries are shifting their product mix in response to new competitors (World Bank 2017). Such information can provide a competitive edge to a country's trade policy. Schemes also need to be developed to provide big data analytics support to small and medium enterprises to guide their future production and export destinations, especially if the traditional trade sectors are to remain globally competitive. Lack of such support can endanger India's international market shares in the traditional export sectors.

Apart from providing digital infrastructure for trade and support for the use of big data analytics to inform trade policy and domestic producers, there is a need to maintain policy space for including DIFTP in future trade and investment agreements, especially the multilateral trade agreements at the WTO. It is essential that no agreement is signed which restricts the policy space for regulating cross-border data flows of the Indian government. Since data is the core resource in a digital economy, it needs to be owned by the national government and stored locally. Data provides a competitive edge in international trade in the digital world. For example, in traditional export sectors like textiles, wearing apparels, and leather products, consumer data provides a competitive advantage as it can be used in conjunction with big data analytics and AI to forecast demand, customise production, and determine international demand. Data localisation restrictions give governments the authority to control and regulate data. However, if data is stored in the cloud by foreign firms outside the national boundary, then governments cannot stop the use or abuse of data by foreign firms as it lies outside their jurisdiction. Further, there is a need to develop national digital skills and digital technologies for which technology transfers from foreign firms become imperative. Any agreements, especially at the multilateral level, that restrict the ability of the governments to control or regulate data and develop national digital skills and technologies through promotion of technology transfer measures should not be signed.

Many proposals on e-commerce that are pending at the WTO can have far-reaching implications on the policy space around data flows (WTO 2016a, 2016b). These proposals, if accepted, will not allow governments to have the freedom to make rules around localisation of data and restricting cross-border flow of data, both of which are needed to enable the governments to own and regulate the data of their citizens. Further, governments will not be able to make policies to encourage technology transfers through source code sharing. Foreign firms, when exporting services to India using digital technologies, need to be encouraged to share their source code. China adopted a policy which forced tech firms to share their source code, set up research and development centres in China, and build hardware and software back doors to enable Chinese officials to monitor their data. The monopolistic powers and anti-competitive practices of international digital platforms also need to be addressed within the DIFTP as the boundaries between trade and investments blur, especially with the rise of digital platforms.

Given the rise in the use of 3D printing and its potential as a future mainstream manufacturing process, it is important to carefully examine proposals regarding custom duties on electronic transmissions in the WTO. The import of computer-aided designs used in 3D printing along with other digitalised products, if not monitored through custom duties, can change the trade patterns of the economy. Many countries like Indonesia are implementing custom duties on electronic transmissions like e-books and software (Jakarta Post 2017). India too needs to consider taking control of products being imported through electronic transmissions with custom duties and oppose the permanent moratorium.

India needs to revisit the traditional approach to foreign trade policy and adapt it to the digital world with an emphasis on regulating and using data, and developing digital infrastructure and Information Technology to promote trade and inform trade policy in order to remain globally competitive. Sri Lanka has formed a Ministry of Digital Infrastructure and Information Technology to build its digital capacities. Such a ministry can draw expertise from other ministries in charge of subjects like ICT, trade, technology, and industry.

Notes

1 Australia, Austria, Belgium, Brazil, Bulgaria Canada, China, Croatia, Cyprus, Czech Republic, Denmark, Estonia, Finland, France, Germany, Greece, Hungary, Indonesia, Ireland, Italy, Japan, Republic of Korea, Latvia, Lithuania, Luxembourg, Malta, Mexico, Netherlands, Norway, Poland, Portugal, Romania, Russian Federation, Slovak Republic, Slovenia, Spain, Sweden, Switzerland, Taiwan China, Turkey, United Kingdom, United States and ROW (rest of the world).

2 For more discussion on "data is the new oil," see UNCTAD (2018).

3 Internet and Mobile Association of India (IAMAI) and ITU.

urn:contentItem:5VKT-36X1-DY0W-446N-00000-00ISIS Leader Killed - RPT; A Show of Unity; Immigration Crackdown; Fiat Chrysler Recall; Ridiculed at Starbucks; Snap Falls to IPO Price;2017-06-16T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:03:11ZLexisNexisISIS Leader Killed - RPT; A Show of Unity; Immigration Crackdown; FiatChrysler Recall; Ridiculed at Starbucks; Snap Falls to IPO Price;LanhamFULL TEXT

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: Live from the U.S. Open in Erin Hills Golf Course in Wisconsin, here's Maria Bartiromo with the special edition of "Mornings with Maria."

MARIA BARTIROMO, FBN HOST: Good Friday morning, everybody, thanks so much for joining us on a glorious Friday morning. I'm Maria Bartiromo, and it is Friday June 16th. Your top stories right now 6:00 A.M. on the East Coast.

Breaking news this morning. The Leader of ISIS reportedly killed. The Associated Press reporting Russia is claiming that it killed Abu Bakr al- Baghdadi in an airstrike in Syria. At this point, the U.S. military cannot confirm the news but we are watching what's coming out of Russia this morning. What it means for the war on terror coming up this morning.

A show of unity yesterday at the congressional baseball game last night, both teams coming together for a prayer for their colleague Congressman Steve Scalise ahead of the first pitch.

And President Trump praise lawmakers in the video message right before.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

DONALD TRUMP, PRESIDENT OF THE UNITED STATES: by playing tonight, you are showing the world that we will not be intimidated by threats, acts of violence or assaults on our democracy. The game will go on.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BARTIROMO: But the unity was short-lived unfortunately. House minority leader Nancy Pelosi already back at it attacking republicans blaming them for the nastiness in politics, what she said, coming up.

Plus, two escaped prisoners back in custody this morning thanks to hero homeowner. He held the two men at gunpoint until authorities arrived.

A massive minivan recall to report. FiatChrysler pulling vehicles off of the road over airbag concerns. We've got the details coming up.

And Snap shares under pressure, the stocks gliding. The lowest IPO price for the first time since going public. Why investors are getting real cautious on Snapchat's parent company Snap. That's coming up.

Plus, a President Trump supporter targeted at Starbucks. The company forced to apologize after a barista handed her cup that read "build a wall" instead of her name.

Futures indicating the markets to open this way. Take a look at where we stand with three and a half hours before opening bell. The Dow industrials expect to open higher this morning. They got the firmer tone. Dow Industrial up 25. NASDAQ up six, S&P 500 up as well.

In Europe, stocks are higher as well. Take a look at the Eurozone indices this morning. And we see gains across the board. The FTSE 100 in London up two-thirds of one percent. And the CAC quarante up three quarters of one percent.

In Asia overnight, markets were mixed at the close. The Asian markets, as you see. Nikkei average in Japan up half a percent. Hang Seng also higher. Although the Shanghai Composite in China was lower.

All those stories coming up this morning. And joining me right now from Erin Hills at the U.S. Open, Fox Business Network's Dagen McDowell, BGC partner, senior strategist and Fox News Contributor, Steve Cortes. Great to see you.

DAGEN MCDOWELL, FBN HOST: Good morning.

STEVE CORTES, FOX NEWS CONTRIBUTOR: Good morning.

BARTIROMO: Beautiful morning here at Erin Hills.

MCDOWELL: And the viewers get to see it but it's impossible to capture even over TV or in word as the suns comes up here. How gorgeous it is.

BARTIROMO: Absolutely beautiful. They were just mowing the lawn, getting ready for tee off in about an hour and a half.

MCDOWELL: It speaks to the kind of hospitality and the warmth and beauty that we've experienced here.

CORTES: It's called welcome to the Midwest.

BARTIROMO: Thank you.

MCDOWELL: I like how you're the self-appointed ambassador and you're from Illinois.

CORTES: I'm from Chicago not very far away. But it is amazing this early in the morning here in the course. The serenity of the place. It won't be serene in a few hours. It'll be ruckus with a lot of people, a lot of golf going on. But it's an incredible setting.

BARTRIOMO: Good word, serenity, I like that.

Meanwhile, ISIS leader apparently reportedly killed. We're going to be talking about that, big story there. President Trump said a long time ago, let Russia help us on this.

CORTES: Maria, and listen, obviously, I think this is -- not that we want to celebrate that but this is good news, I think for the world and you're exactly right. I'm clearly a President Trump partisan. We worked hard in his campaign. But he was right that we have no allusions that Russia is our friend, generally. I think they're more foe than friend. But there are times when we have common interest. And when it comes to ISIS, we have a very common interest in the Islamist terror. And so we should welcome their participation and their help and I think this is great news.

BARTRIOMO: Well, this is great news if they actually killed the leader of ISIS which is what we're hearing this morning.

Coming up this morning joining the conversation the CEO of Kalahari Resort, Todd Nelson is with us this morning. President of the Jacob Leinenkugel Brewing Company, Dick Leinenkugel is with us. Texas Congressman Brian Babin is here. And the CEO of Harley-Davidson, Matt Levatich is with us as well.

We've got a big show ahead. So do stay with us throughout.

First off, we kick it off right now to the -- with what could be a major military victory for Russia. The country this morning is claiming that it may have killed ISIS leader Abu Bakr al-Baghdadi in Syria. In a statement issued to Russian news agencies, the defense ministries says that the country's Air Force struck a meeting of ISIS leaders outside of Raqqa, Syria. The group's de facto capital possibly killing Baghdadi late last month.

A top U.S. military spokesperson tells Fox News they cannot confirm the report at this time, previous reports of al-Baghdadi death has been false. Raqqa, of course, has been attacked on the ground and by the air by American-backed Kurdish and Arab forces which have been closing in on the terrorist group in recent weeks.

Joining us right now, republican congressman Chuck Fleischmann of Tennessee. Congressman, thank you so much for joining us.

CHUCK FLEISCHMANN, U.S. REPRESENTATIVE, TENNESSEE: Good morning.

BARTRIOMO: If true, how significant a development is this in the fight against ISIS?

FLEISCHMANN: Oh, it's very significant. There needs to be a world combat against ISIS. ISIS has been bad. They have grown, they have spread like a cancer and anytime that we can take out one of their leaders or deter their horrible agenda, it's a victory for mankind.

BARTIROMO: Will we get actual confirmation? I mean, how long do you think until we know this is actually fact? Because I know there have been a lot of rumors that he -- over the last several years, in fact?

FLEISCHMANN: The fact that the rumors are that the Russians actually did it, it may take a while for the intelligence community to pick that up and to get confirmation. But ultimately, whether it was Jihadi John or anybody else who had a horrible agenda like ISIS, any of these terrorist leaders, when they have been killed, the truth ultimately always comes out.

BARTIROMO: It sure would be. We are live from beautiful Erin Hills this morning in Wisconsin. We are at the 117th U.S. Open, and you just heard top tour golfer share why Father's Day this Sunday is so important to them. The holiday rakes major bucks for retailers. Americans are expected to spend a record high $15.5 billion this year, on Father's Day gifts. I want to bring in CEO and President of the PGA Tour Superstore, Dick Sullivan is with us. Dick, it's great to see you. Thanks so much for joining us.

DICK SULLIVAN, PGA TOUR SUPERSTORE PRESIDENT: Thanks, Maria. Great to be here. I wish I was with you, though. It looks beautiful out there.

BARTIROMO: We wish you were. It is gorgeous here, of course, the U.S. Open is traditionally held during the week of Father's Day. Tell us how events are driving sales at your superstore.

SULLIVAN: This is a huge week for us actually the biggest week of the year. Our number one week, only I think Christmas is number two, so we are having a great season. Actually seven and the last eight months, we had double-digit comp store increases which are significant in brick-and-mortar retail world. And our online has tripled those. This is a huge week for us. We got a lot of great gifts, this weekend will be -- this week will break a record for our company. This will be the biggest week as I said, of the year.

BARTIROMO: In fact, you've got great products right here with us. We're going to help out last-minute shoppers' check out some of the products that we have on set. Get your take on this. First, we've got a Callaway GBD Epic Driver.

SULLIVAN: This is the newest, hottest driver in the market. It just came out January, and it's got new technology they call jailbreak technology, got titanium in front of the club face, clearly the number one driver. A great gift for dad. We have many of them in our stores so people should come to our stores and buy them this weekend.

BARTIROMO: Tell us about your range finders. What is the Bushnell technology offering?

SULLIVAN: It's unbelievable these days. You can shoot them, and shoot handle will vibrate. It's all about distance and accuracy. They're so much better than in the past.

BARTIROMO: Yes Dagen, what do you got there?

DAGEN MCDOWELL, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK ANCHOR: I don't know. He can tell us the number one -

BARTIROMO: We're holding this putter here. It's got lights on it.

SULLIVAN: I can't see what you are looking at. That tailor-made part - that's the part that Rory just put into play. That is one of the hottest putters clearly. Jason Day is playing that putter; Sergio won with that putter at the Masters. It's heavy as you can see. It's more stable, allows for better role. It's a great putter and those guys playing really well with it as you see.

BARTIROMO: Jordan Spieth, one of golf's greatest moneymakers his deal with Under Armour has introduced must-have products on the course. Does the store carry anything from Under Armour?

SULLIVAN: We carry all the apparel from Under Armour. We carry shirts, pants. This is a new Spieth One shoe. And golf shoes have come a long way, not just about the look of the shoe, it is about performance. These are very, very lightweight. These are in stores at $199, another great gift for dad and these are designed by Jordan. And worked with Jordan with team Under Armour.

BARTIROMO: We came prepared. Let me ask you about these balls. Number one golf ball and then, this ball engineered to perform with every club. Tell us about these balls.

SULLIVAN: Well, the titlist is the number one gift in the store for sure. It's the number one ball played in all the tours, there is more pros playing Titlist Pro V1 than any other ball I think combined. The new ball is Taylor made TP 5.

BARTIROMO: How much are these balls?

SULLIVAN: The golf balls are 47.99 for titlist Pro V, Taylor made ball is a new ball. Actually, Justin Rose hit it. He's getting more height but getting the same distance so the ball is landing on the green.

BARTIROMO: Amazing. Dick Sullivan, thank you. Don't miss our live coverage of the U.S. Open on Fox Sports Go, Fox Sports One, back in a minute.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

BARTIROMO: That will do it for us. Someone is going to be walking home with this beauty, soon. Have a great weekend, everybody. Here is "VARNEY & COMPANY" and Stuart. Stu, take it away.

END

So I think we certainly have an administration in the White House right now who is business friendly, who knows that if we need employment -- if we're going to have employment, really accelerate, not the kind of tepid employment gains that we've seen lately. We have to be pro-employer. And part of that is the regulatory framework, the regulatory ...
