Document.Content:
urn:contentItem:5NV2-0G31-DY0W-438W-00000-00ISIS Leader Killed - RPT; A Show of Unity; Immigration Crackdown; Fiat Chrysler Recall; Ridiculed at Starbucks; Snap Falls to IPO Price;2017-06-16T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:03:11ZLexisNexisISIS Leader Killed - RPT; A Show of Unity; Immigration Crackdown; FiatChrysler Recall; Ridiculed at Starbucks; Snap Falls to IPO Price;LanhamFULL TEXT

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: Live from the U.S. Open in Erin Hills Golf Course in Wisconsin, here's Maria Bartiromo with the special edition of "Mornings with Maria."

MARIA BARTIROMO, FBN HOST: Good Friday morning, everybody, thanks so much for joining us on a glorious Friday morning. I'm Maria Bartiromo, and it is Friday June 16th. Your top stories right now 6:00 A.M. on the East Coast.

Breaking news this morning. The Leader of ISIS reportedly killed. The Associated Press reporting Russia is claiming that it killed Abu Bakr al- Baghdadi in an airstrike in Syria. At this point, the U.S. military cannot confirm the news but we are watching what's coming out of Russia this morning. What it means for the war on terror coming up this morning.

A show of unity yesterday at the congressional baseball game last night, both teams coming together for a prayer for their colleague Congressman Steve Scalise ahead of the first pitch.

And President Trump praise lawmakers in the video message right before.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

DONALD TRUMP, PRESIDENT OF THE UNITED STATES: by playing tonight, you are showing the world that we will not be intimidated by threats, acts of violence or assaults on our democracy. The game will go on.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BARTIROMO: But the unity was short-lived unfortunately. House minority leader Nancy Pelosi already back at it attacking republicans blaming them for the nastiness in politics, what she said, coming up.

Plus, two escaped prisoners back in custody this morning thanks to hero homeowner. He held the two men at gunpoint until authorities arrived.

A massive minivan recall to report. FiatChrysler pulling vehicles off of the road over airbag concerns. We've got the details coming up.

And Snap shares under pressure, the stocks gliding. The lowest IPO price for the first time since going public. Why investors are getting real cautious on Snapchat's parent company Snap. That's coming up.

Plus, a President Trump supporter targeted at Starbucks. The company forced to apologize after a barista handed her cup that read "build a wall" instead of her name.

Futures indicating the markets to open this way. Take a look at where we stand with three and a half hours before opening bell. The Dow industrials expect to open higher this morning. They got the firmer tone. Dow Industrial up 25. NASDAQ up six, S&P 500 up as well.

In Europe, stocks are higher as well. Take a look at the Eurozone indices this morning. And we see gains across the board. The FTSE 100 in London up two-thirds of one percent. And the CAC quarante up three quarters of one percent.

In Asia overnight, markets were mixed at the close. The Asian markets, as you see. Nikkei average in Japan up half a percent. Hang Seng also higher. Although the Shanghai Composite in China was lower.

All those stories coming up this morning. And joining me right now from Erin Hills at the U.S. Open, Fox Business Network's Dagen McDowell, BGC partner, senior strategist and Fox News Contributor, Steve Cortes. Great to see you.

DAGEN MCDOWELL, FBN HOST: Good morning.

STEVE CORTES, FOX NEWS CONTRIBUTOR: Good morning.

BARTIROMO: Beautiful morning here at Erin Hills.

MCDOWELL: And the viewers get to see it but it's impossible to capture even over TV or in word as the suns comes up here. How gorgeous it is.

BARTIROMO: Absolutely beautiful. They were just mowing the lawn, getting ready for tee off in about an hour and a half.

MCDOWELL: It speaks to the kind of hospitality and the warmth and beauty that we've experienced here.

CORTES: It's called welcome to the Midwest.

BARTIROMO: Thank you.

MCDOWELL: I like how you're the self-appointed ambassador and you're from Illinois.

CORTES: I'm from Chicago not very far away. But it is amazing this early in the morning here in the course. The serenity of the place. It won't be serene in a few hours. It'll be ruckus with a lot of people, a lot of golf going on. But it's an incredible setting.

BARTRIOMO: Good word, serenity, I like that.

Meanwhile, ISIS leader apparently reportedly killed. We're going to be talking about that, big story there. President Trump said a long time ago, let Russia help us on this.

CORTES: Maria, and listen, obviously, I think this is -- not that we want to celebrate that but this is good news, I think for the world and you're exactly right. I'm clearly a President Trump partisan. We worked hard in his campaign. But he was right that we have no allusions that Russia is our friend, generally. I think they're more foe than friend. But there are times when we have common interest. And when it comes to ISIS, we have a very common interest in the Islamist terror. And so we should welcome their participation and their help and I think this is great news.

BARTRIOMO: Well, this is great news if they actually killed the leader of ISIS which is what we're hearing this morning.

Coming up this morning joining the conversation the CEO of Kalahari Resort, Todd Nelson is with us this morning. President of the Jacob Leinenkugel Brewing Company, Dick Leinenkugel is with us. Texas Congressman Brian Babin is here. And the CEO of Harley-Davidson, Matt Levatich is with us as well.

We've got a big show ahead. So do stay with us throughout.

First off, we kick it off right now to the -- with what could be a major military victory for Russia. The country this morning is claiming that it may have killed ISIS leader Abu Bakr al-Baghdadi in Syria. In a statement issued to Russian news agencies, the defense ministries says that the country's Air Force struck a meeting of ISIS leaders outside of Raqqa, Syria. The group's de facto capital possibly killing Baghdadi late last month.

A top U.S. military spokesperson tells Fox News they cannot confirm the report at this time, previous reports of al-Baghdadi death has been false. Raqqa, of course, has been attacked on the ground and by the air by American-backed Kurdish and Arab forces which have been closing in on the terrorist group in recent weeks.

Joining us right now, republican congressman Chuck Fleischmann of Tennessee. Congressman, thank you so much for joining us.

CHUCK FLEISCHMANN, U.S. REPRESENTATIVE, TENNESSEE: Good morning.

BARTRIOMO: If true, how significant a development is this in the fight against ISIS?

FLEISCHMANN: Oh, it's very significant. There needs to be a world combat against ISIS. ISIS has been bad. They have grown, they have spread like a cancer and anytime that we can take out one of their leaders or deter their horrible agenda, it's a victory for mankind.

BARTIROMO: Will we get actual confirmation? I mean, how long do you think until we know this is actually fact? Because I know there have been a lot of rumors that he -- over the last several years, in fact?

FLEISCHMANN: The fact that the rumors are that the Russians actually did it, it may take a while for the intelligence community to pick that up and to get confirmation. But ultimately, whether it was Jihadi John or anybody else who had a horrible agenda like ISIS, any of these terrorist leaders, when they have been killed, the truth ultimately always comes out.

MCDOWELL: Congressman, it's Dagen McDowell. But as significant as this might be the killing of Abu Bakr al-Baghdadi, American are worried, Europeans are certainly worried about homegrown terrorists.

FLEISCHMANN: Absolutely.

MCDOWELL: That that's one of the biggest and major concerns. So to that point, what is law enforcement, what are the intelligence agencies doing different or doing an addition to what they have been doing to make sure that these individuals are rooted out?

FLEISCHMANN: Well, let me say this, I experienced homegrown terrorism in Chattanooga, Tennessee, my hometown, where we lost five brave, great soldiers and sailors. There's a horrible attack. So unfortunately, people have been radicalized. The step in the right direction would be to do what I did. I entered a bill -- or introduced a bill in the house to basically combat terrorism here in America.

So we're trying to combat radicalization wherever it is but I think we do a better job abroad sometimes than we actually do in the United States. And I think our intelligence community is catching up with the reality that these people with a bad agenda whether it's ISIS, Al-Qaeda or any group of radical Islamic terrorism has got to be stopped and the best way to do that is to combat their hateful ideology with proper education and to reach out and tell people exactly what they are doing. And one of the best tools in -- and my bill basically was going to do this. It was going to take people who had informally part of this bad organization who had been radicalized, who've seen the light, who turned good and basically they were going to be used to combat the spread of this radical horrible ideology.

BARTIROMO: Congressman, let me turn out to the congressional baseball game last night.

FLEISCHMANN: Thank you.

BARTIROMO: Of course, you witnessed the shooting of your fellow colleague Steve Scalise and others on Wednesday morning. You were there, you played in the game last night. How did it feel to be out on that field last night?

FLEISCHMANN: It was probably one of the most special moments that I've experienced in my entire lifetime. Since I've been in congress, I've seen carnage, I alluded to the fact that we lost the five brave Americans in Chattanooga a couple years ago. Last night, after having experienced just the day before the horrors of a gunman, a madman, we saw a great healing. We showed the American people that whether we're republicans, whether we're democrats, whether we're partisans or nonpartisans that we do unite when it comes to the important things.

Baseball is a great American sport. I've played it since I've been five years old. I'll be 55 in October. As my coaches telling me, I'm still good. I went out there last night and I gave it all but I gave my heart to Representative Scalise, to Mr. Mica, to the capitol police officers who've been wounded, actually saving our lives, it's the beginning of a long healing process.

BARTIROMO: Can you give us an update on Steve Scalise? Do you know anything new in terms of his condition?

FLEISCHMANN: I do not, other than I heard thank God he was improving. I am so thankful that President Trump and Vice President Pence have been able to visit him. And I just hope and pray for his full recovery. He is a dear friend. He's more than a colleague. He is a dear friend. We have played baseball together. We have surfed together. And he's just a great American and my heart goes out to him and his family and I pray for a full and speedy recovery for all involved.

BARTIROMO: Yes, he is. Thank you so much, congressman. It's good to have you on the program this morning. We'll be watching, thank you. Congressman Chuck Fleischmann there.

Coming up next, President Trump cracking down on illegal immigration, cancelling the Obama era policy that protected some from deportation. How the change will impact Homeland Security? We're covering that next.

Then FiatChrysler recalls nearly 300,000 cars as the auto company says airbags may unintentionally deploy in certain vehicles. We've got the details straight-ahead after this break. Back in a moment.

(MUSIC)

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

BARTIROMO: Welcome back. President Trump scrapping in immigration policy from the Obama administration which protected immigrant parents from being deported. Lauren Simonetti on all details right now. Headlines in New York. Lauren.

LAUREN SIMONETTI, FBN CORRESPONDENT: Hi, Maria. Happy Friday, everybody. President Trump making good on another one of his key campaign promises. Homeland Security Secretary John Kelly formally revoking the program aimed at protecting parents and of U.S. citizens and legal residents from being deported.

President Obama announced the program back in 2014 but it was never fully launched because it was apparently blocked by a federal court. Republicans criticizing the effort calling it back door amnesty.

Well, Fiat Chrysler recalling 297,000 minivans in North America for wiring problem that can lead to unintended airbag deployment. The recall of 2011 and '12 model year Dodge Grand Caravan minivans has been linked to eight minor injuries. The recall will begin in late July. Dealers will replace the wiring if needed and add protective covering.

Say it isn't so. Butterfingers. Nestle putting its candy business up for sale. The Swiss company trying to get a healthier bottom line as customers are on the world demand healthier snacks. The unit could be worth as much as $3 billion.

And have you guys seen this one? A loyal Starbucks customer in Charlotte, North Carolina says she was targeted for supporting Donald Trump. Kayla Hart walked into a Starbucks, as she usually does. This time she was wearing a Donald Trump t-shirt and look at this. She said her order was labeled with that political message "build a wall" instead of her name and she was ridiculed for it.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

KAYLA HART: Build a wall and kind of shoves my drink at me and then all of the baristas in the back started cracking up laughing.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

SIMONETTI: Hart says she's waiting to hear from the Starbucks district manager before deciding whether she's going to give them her business once again, Maria. Unbelievable.

BARTIROMO: Wow. All right, Lauren. Thank you so much. Lauren Simonetti. That term doesn't seem like a negative insult to me and I would have said, great. You would have left.

CORTES: I would have absolutely left. I will tell you this. As a Trump guy who campaigned for Trump and who was -- I was accosted on public transportation several times, complete strangers. And far worst turns in that. I don't think that's insulting, by the way. Trump campaigned on build a wall. So I think --

BARTIROMO: But they were laughing at her, that's why she was upset.

CORTES: And I'm sure they were trying to ridicule her. And here's the thing too. I think it is important -- I think Dagen was mentioning off camera that a lot of us have lost our sense of humor when it comes to politics. Politics had become such blood sport. Our country is so divided. There's times that we can't laugh about it and there are some things that we should laugh about it. To me, if somebody showed me that cup of build a wall, that's funny.

BARTIROMO: Yes. And I would have been like, yeah, build that wall.

MCDOWELL: Again, humor has just disappeared in the world of political discourse. Could everybody so offended by everything? I say bring it back.

BARTIROMO: I think that's the right word that he said blood sport. It has become blood sport.

CORTES: Maria, I do think too. On a more serious point though too, why are we so divided? Right? And I think we're the most divided. We should have been my lifetime and from my read of history, maybe the most since the civil war, I think possibly, 60's were pretty divisive from what I can gather. I wasn't around then. But in my lifetime I the most divided we've been. But why?

I think a couple of reasons. One is identity politics which I think have just run a muck, constantly identifying ourselves by our ethnic group, by our gender. I think that that has reached - has extenuated division. And then I think secondly and most importantly, slow economic growth. Economic anxiety always exacerbates whatever other tensions exist.

MCDOWELL: Quote Bill Murray and strikes lighten up. That will actually reduce a lot of the anger and rage and divisiveness if people can just kind of step back and take a breath.

BARTIROMO: That's a good point.

Still ahead, safety concerns for navy jet pilots to report. Fox News correspondent Lea Gabrielle will explain why training is currently at a standstill for trainees. We'll get into it next.

Then our investors losing confidence in Snap. What about the whole tech sector? The fallout after Snap sunk to its IPO price to $70 a share and then broke it yesterday. Back in a minute.

(MUSIC)

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

BARTIROMO: Welcome back. Let's take a look at Snap. This was one of the big stories in the stock market yesterday. It has been anything but picture perfect for the company. Since it's Wall Street debut, Snap shares fell to the IPO price yesterday of $17 a share. And you know, we have seen some churn going on in technology in general, right? A lot of those big tech names that have been the leadership of this market last year have turned over. What do you think about is?

CORTES: Maria, I'll say and I've been on air pretty critical of Snapchat and mainly because here's my sort of grand thesis, is that they sell for free a product to a lot of people who generally don't have money, teenagers. But having said that, people -- I've got three teen daughters at home, they live on Snap. I mean, absolutely live on it. They don't text --

BARTIROMO: But how do you monetize it? Are they making money?

CORTES: but here's the caveat to all of that and that's my negative comment on Snap. But here's my positive comment and this just happened, I believe, this week, McDonald's is hiring a quarter million workers and they're going to do it via Snap. They want their applications to come which is very interesting to me. That's very intriguing, it made me rethink my bearish opinion of the company that if this can become a bit of a teenager or millennial LinkedIn, well, that's utility then. That's not just sort of fun and silliness and that might be a way that they can actually monetize.

So anyway, makes me rethink at least. Back of the IPO price for somebody who's been pretty skeptical of the company, I'm rethinking that.

MCDOWELL: The issue I have always had with Snap is that it doesn't have that high barrier to entry and you've seen Facebook and Facebooks, Instagram innovating on this front and really rolling out Snap-like features to not only hang onto their existing user base -- but also -- it's a little windy here at the U.S. Open. But also to draw -- this is millennials age, draw people away from Snapchat and I think that that was something that wasn't priced into the IPO initially, the ease with which that customers can leave Snapchat.

BARTIROMO: What do you think about the other tech names? You're talking about Amazon, Google, all of the names, Apple, that have been really the leadership of this market and yet, we're seeing a bit of a pullback?

CORTES: I think that it's natural, to put it in context, I think compared with the rally that they saw, particularly since the election, it's not that material.

BARTIROMO: But look at this chart right here.

CORTES: Well, I mean, those things are very volatile if you just got in.

BARTIROMO: This week for Amazon.

CORTES: But I also think to connect the dots here between markets and politics. It's ironic to me that Silicon Valley which is a place where President Trump is probably not terribly popular, I don't think they're going to hold a parade.

MCDOWELL: That was the understatement of more than so far.

CORTES: But it's been wonderful for Silicon Valley.

BARTIROMO: And next week, the White House is having a technology summit, all the CEO's of big tech companies have signed on. They're going to go to the White House. They're going to talk about modernizing government.

MCDOWELL: They certainly want tax reform. Corporate tax reform. And that was one thing that universally every tech CEO was excited about. So they're going to give the president and the White House staff an earful about pushing that harder -- pushing those republicans in congress on that much harder than they have been.

BARTIROMO: Dagen, then there's Twitter. Looking to jazz up the brand. The company rolls out a new design on both the website and the app. We're using Twitter all the time. I just tweeted out the shot of them hosing and getting the golf course ready. Is this enough you think to keep investors happy?

MCDOWELL: No. I still think that Twitter wind up getting bought by somebody. Because it does have a great installed user base. A professionals who use Twitter for basically a news delivery service. That's how you use it. But I think in the last week, you've seen one of the major problems with Twitter and that is the level of hate speech and vitriol and partisan name calling that has been a problem and that's one of the reasons that a lot of these potential acquirers of Twitter have turned away from it because they don't want to be associated with that and you can't monetize nastiness.

BARTIROMO: Same problem though. How do you monetize?

CORTES: I do think you're right, Dagen, though. I do think that there is a floor relatively close because of that takeover potential. I'm not saying that means necessarily buy the stock, but I do think there's somewhat of an embedded --

BARTIROMO: Who wants it? We've been down this road before. Nobody want it.

CORTES: And I will say the same time. Look, when you have the president of the United States who has become the Twitter in chief who lives on this medium and it still can't seem to monetize, right? That I will admit that's a problem, that comes from somebody, I use it all day every day for business reasons, for sports reasons, for fun, it's incredible but I don't spend a dime.

MCDOWELL: That goes to the point though. If you say you follow President Trump and you retweet everything that he does, Twitter identifies that, what are they going to sell to you? What ads are they going to serve to you other than "Make America Great Again" hats and t-shirts? What does that say about what type of shampoo or laundry detergent you like? It doesn't say anything, quite frankly.

CORTES: They do get also one interesting trivia so it wouldn't be this one but the previous one in 1898, I forget the guy's name but whoever won it was apparently a very heavy drinker, they were worry that he would hack it for drinking money, had to put it -- he had a cool story, he had to put on a deposit to keep it for the year --

BARTIROMO: Oh my God.

CORTES: -- but they keep -- and also interesting, when you look at the names on here, I don't know, the viewers probably can't see it but one thing you certainly notice is a very few repeats, only two people have ever won twice in a row and after DJ started yesterday it seems like probably not going to happen again this year. We're going to have a new winner, it looks like.

BARTIROMO: Yes, and just think the way it's engraved, it's so beautiful. I don't even want to touch it, it's so gorgeous.

CORTES: Right.

MCDOWELL: No, they told me I wasn't allowed to touch it --

BARTIROMO: Oh, then I won't try to --

MCDOWELL: No, I'm just kidding. I'm just -- because I break things, so I have to keep my -- it has a restraining order against me.

BARTIROMO: It's absolutely beautiful. Sterling silver, the trophy right here and somebody's going to be walking home with that on this tournament and keeping it a for a year. Breaking news, President Trump just tweeting, here is what he say in this morning, "The Fake News Media hates when I use what has turned out to be my very powerful Social Media. Over 100 million people I can go around them." He is fired up this morning, Steve Cortes.

CORTES: You know, listen, make tweeting great again. It was -- I'm going to defend the president on this. I love that he tweets and even a lot of people who like him and who support him say, "Gosh, I wish he'd hold back on the Twitter," I think this is so important that number one, he can connect directly with the American people, there's no mediators anymore, but I think the secondly, most of the mainstream media is so utterly antagonistic toward the president and I frankly don't even think that's really very debatable.

BARTIROMO: Yes.

CORTES: And the amount of fake news that's put out about him, one just recent example, Washington Post saying that Comey asked for more money and then he was -- for the Russian investigation and that's why he was fired. Completely false --

BARTIROMO: Oh my God.

CORTES: -- utterly, utterly false --

BARTIROMO: All right. We will --

CORTES: -- so the president has to go directly to the people.

BARTIROMO: Yes, and that's what he's doing. We'll take a break. When we come back, Kroger getting clobbered. The grocery store giant shares of plummeting this morning after putting lower profits. How the company plans to turn that around. Then going hot wild, the CEO of Harley-Davidson is with us live to talk about the company's deep Wisconsin roots and talk about President Trump's impact on business since taking office. Trade, taxes, Harley-Davidson, next.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

MARIA BARTIROMO, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK MORNINGS WITH MARIA HOST: Welcome back, thanks so much for joining us. Happy Friday everybody I'm Maria Bartiromo, and we are coming to you live this morning from the U.S. Open, it is Friday, June 16th. Your top stories right now, 8:30 a.m. on the east coast, President Trump takes on Cuba the Commander in Chief sets to unveil today a new policy, toward the island nation. FOX NEWS confirming that the action will include strict enforcement of travel exemption between U.S. and Cuba.

We're watching shares of Kroger this morning, the grocery chain under pressure, stock is selling off, in a growing competition in the sector we've got a closer look coming up this morning, at Kroger. And from clicks to bricks details on Amazon new patent that could stop in store customers from comparing the company prices online. If you're using their Wi-Fi they're in control.

Futures showing the markets will open this way we are well off of the highs of the morning we're seeing some selling under way this morning Dow industrials expected to be up but just about eight points now that's well off the highs, of earlier, something is happening, where this market is turning as we speak as you see there. In Europe, stocks are higher across the board although, there too were off of the highs as you see here, F.T- 100, CAC Quarante up two-thirds of one percent, DAX Index up just a quarter of a percent. And in Asia overnight markets finished mixed take a look at the markets there, the best performer is Japan up one-half of one percent.

An action-packed day the first day of the U.S. Open yesterday, Rickie Fowler at top of the leader.

We will show you how you can have your dad look like the pros this father's day. We've got all the gifts you want to know about. We are live here in beautiful Erin Hills in Wisconsin, for the 117th U.S. Open, of course, one of the staples of the state is Harley-Davidson the legendary motorcycle brand was founded in Milwaukee Wisconsin back in 1903, I am sporting a hot Harley jacket right now. A wardrobe change as we welcome the CEO of Harley- Davidson, Matthew Levatich joining us here, Matt great to see you again.

MATTHEW LEVATICH, HARLEY-DAVIDSON CHIEF EXECUTIVE OFFICER: Nice to see you, Maria.

BARTIROMO: Thank you so much for joining us, thank you very much. So you've been committed to creating jobs in America your name comes up a lot with President Trump, characterize the jobs market for us what you're seeing in terms of the broader economy.

LEVATICH: Well you know as you mentioned we've been here from the very beginning 1903, our engine plant is still in Milwaukee and Milwaukee's got a long and proud history of a lot of not only manufacturing with technology and development, and so the skilled trades element of what we see in a workforce is very important. So far we're having great success with the employment that we need, the broader economy I think for the company and for, you know, the United States, for us, is a lot about our opportunities to grow internationally. So trade is very important and we're paying a lot of attention to the trade policies and the trade opportunities that we have particularly in Asia, which is the world largest motorcycle market are in Asia, our biggest growth potential, is in Asia and so the trade barriers trade tariffs are obviously top of mind as we look to pursue those goals.

BARTIROMO: I want to talk about that because when President Trump speaks about trade he's come up with this idea of a reciprocal tax and I think it's partly because of your story, because when you sell motorcycles in India they charge you what a 100 percent or 90 percent?

LEVATICH: One hundred percent tariff on a straight import.

BARTIROMO: A 100 percent tariff to India and you're charge to 90 percent tariff in China.

LEVATICH: Yes, and throughout that region actually the tariffs in the entire tax structure add a significant amount of burden to the product before it gets to retail, and that limits our ability to access and reach those customers we have a lot of passion for Harley in the region, again their big motorcycle markets their growing and we see opportunity but those tax and trade barriers are significant for us, as a limitation to that growth.

BARTIROMO: This has been one of the most important examples, that President Trump has discussed your story, the fact that you're selling motorcycles overseas and they're giving you this huge tariff and were not putting those kinds of tariffs on their products when they're coming here. So do you favor something like that, I mean how do you alleviate these 100 percent tariffs if China and India are not going to change their -

LEVATICH: Well, you know, the whole trade environment can't be taken in isolated cases and so it's a very complex issue clearly we are heavily invested U.S. manufacturer we are exporting our products around the world 90 countries so a direct offset of imported motorcycles is not something that's easily, sort of, simple, sort of, contained a solution, and you know, in something like TPP was in negotiation for almost a decade before it was unfortunately turned down, right? That would have helped us a lot we're optimistic the administration understands the issues that we face and our working on our behalf of as well as on behalf of many here American companies.

BARTIROMO: I mean isn't it interesting that the biggest markets for you are in Asia, and this is where they are actually charging they know that this is a big market for you and they are going to make sure you may up for it.

LEVATICH: Well, that's I guess one interpretation, it is what it is and we're working every angle that we can, to open those markets, because the customers are there, they are interested as those economies as disposable income-leisure time expands, it's a right market for Harley-Davidson our competitors are there oftentimes without the burdens that we have. And we need to find ways to access those markets.

BARTIROMO: Well you are obviously an iconic brand, got a loyal following all around the world. Tell us about what you're seeing a lot of people talking about the retail environment being under pressure we saw that from retail sales we may have seen that even from your earnings I don't know if that's what you saw.

LEVATICH: You know, there's still a lot of uncertainty in the market many people are participating in the economy but they're participating in ways that are I think easily kind of turned on and turned off their watching to see sustained and significant momentum in the economy job security income security those types of things. So that sort of tempted in this, I think affects companies like Harley, you know, we're selling a product that is an aspiration product it's some people dream to have and if they don't have that kind of security they might hold off and wait. And I think that's, that's an aspect of the economy that's still with us.

BARTIROMO: And how do you attract newer generations?

LEVATICH: That's very important to us we are fundamentally about riding, you know, when you look around the beautiful country sided here around Erin Hills this is where the company was founded this is where I like to come and ride beautiful rolling hills and scenic roads. I think our founders were doing the same thing at the very beginning, it is for us all about riding, and creating and recreating the passion for motorcycling is really core to our strategy for the next decade. So it's not simple thing to do but just reminding ourselves that we are in the business of riding and to make sure that we have the full attention of not just we build motorcycles but we build riders, because we have to invest in our sport and remind people how awesome it is to be out riding a motorcycle.

BARTIROMO: Did you ride your bike here today?

LEVATICH: I did not because they would not let me into Erin Hills on a motorcycle oddly enough.

BARTIROMO: What?

LEVATICH: You know this golf community I don't know what they're thinking.

BARTIROMO: Exactly but you sell a lot of other products other than bikes this jacket for example.

LEVATICH: This jacket.

BARTIROMO: Is gorgeous your jacket, tell us about the pricing for the bikes today and what is the range?

LEVATICH: We have we cover a range jackets for a lot broader that most people think you can get into Harley for in this high 6,000, 7,000's, and then of course we produce motorcycles that are for the aspirational owner that are kind in the high 30s and obviously there are lot of differences across that range but we cover that whole price spectrum with Harley- Davidson motorcycles and part of what we need to do is do a better job informing people that there's something for everybody.

BARTIROMO: Especially when you something wants custom made you do that.

LEVATICH: Yes, we have custom vehicle operations heavily accessorized and bigger engines, and you know the real ultimate product for the ultimate passionate customer. But again we've got a lot of stuff in between, a real and their all great there are all high impact, really cool looking, for young adults for women for whomever.

BARTIROMO: Well I -- this is quite cool looking if I say so myself.

LEVATICH: You look -

BARTIROMO: Matt great to have you on the show today.

LEVATICH: Thanks for appreciating it. Nice to see you.

BARTIROMO: Thank you so much, Matthew Levatich is the CEO of Harley- Davidson, we'll take a short break when we come back a wild start to the U.S. Open Stuart Varney gives us a take on the tournament so far. And then Amazon patents hypocrisy, why the company wants to stop customers from comparing prices with competitors after revolutionizing the way we prize, back in a minute

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

BARTIROMO: Welcome back we are coming to you live today from the beautiful Erin Hills a golf course for 117th U.S. Open this morning, here in Wisconsin. Tee-off has begun and we are watching the day begin, welcome back we are looking at markets this morning, a turning negative here, as you saw earlier we were looking at a firmer beginning, and that has pretty much evaporated. The Dow Industrials now showing a gain at just two points, Nasdaq is now negative, that's down two points and the S&P 500, just holding in positive territory by a quarter of a point, so markets have turned decidedly mixed at this point.

The couple of names were watching this morning, Kroger definitely one to watch in terms of volume and movement the stock of the grocery giant fell nearly 20 percent yesterday after company cut its full year for earnings forecast. Kroger is blaming the move on higher product cost, Kroger shares right now as you see continuing that slide, down another two percent this morning.

We're also watching Amazon, the company has been granted a patent that can stop in store shopper from comparing prices on their phones. So when you're shopping around this technology will allow the store to see what a shopper is searching for connected to its Wi-Fi. The store can intake action like an e-mail or a coupon to suggest the comparable item or it can even block access to the competitive content.

so if you are looking for a cheaper price on something, away from Amazon might not be able to find it while in Amazon store. Pretty incredible move from Amazon. Stock is up today. Meanwhile, round two will kick off in Wisconsin for the 117th U.S. Open.

Joining me right now, host of "VARNEY & COMPANY," Stuart Varney who is a regular watcher of golf. Stu, good morning to you.

STUART VARNEY, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK VARNEY AND COMPANY HOST: Maria, point of correction not kickoff in golf, you tee-off. You blast off, that is you tee-off. I want it if possible.

BARTIROMO: That is kicking off, Stu. I have been saying that it is tee- off time all morning, but, of course, you have not been watching all morning.

VARNEY: Yes, I have glued.

BARTIROMO: You really wish you were here.

VARNEY: I do, I do, I do. I want you to make a special point of going over to Rickie Fowler, congratulating him on being seven under, I think latest on the board. I want you to tell him that we miss his fashion sense. He used to appear in most outrageous colors, outfits, really stood out, then all of a sudden he grew up. I don't know what happened, he changed and now he's a normal looking golf type guy. So just have a quick word with him, Maria, and straighten him out when you get the chance.

BARTIROMO: Stu, aren't there rules that you are not supposed to wear stuff like that on the golf course? I mean, I know in tennis you really have to stick to the wardrobe rules.

VARNEY: Now you are talking about Wimbledon. It remains white shirt, white shorts whatever. I think everybody else is -

BARTIROMO: There are no kinds of rules in golf? VARNEY: I don't think so. You can you can't have a Coca-Cola shirt. You can't do that at Masters. I don't know about at U.S. Open. If Rickie Fowler wants to arrive in his pantaloons or whatever you want to call them, that's the one. If you wanted to arrive looking like that, I'd be cheering him on.

BARTIROMO: That's true. You know Stu, I have taken golf lessons just so you know. I took lessons with best of the best. I have a shot to show you, Stuart. I don't want to get you jealous or anything but Hank Haney gave me golf tips. Hank Haney of course, Tiger Woods coach. He was showing me how to putt. Quite exciting.

VARNEY: So Maria, without too far on the -

BARTIROMO: I'm not actually a neophyte in golf as you say.

VARNEY: I am not done yet, Maria. Hold on. Don't cut my segment short here.

BARTIROMO: I'm not good. I never said I was good, Stuart. OK? I just -- I got lessons and then never played again.

VARNEY: I will let you into a secret of mine. I have only played once and played nine holes only at the South Hampton Princess in Bermuda. You know what my score was for nine holes? 118. So I quit playing, I caddied and I watched all the time.

BARTIROMO: Good move.

VARNEY: Yes. I think so.

BARTIROMO: Stuart, happy father's day my friend.

VARNEY: Thank you very much indeed, Maria. And the same to all of you and your staff right there.

BARTIROMO: We will see you 10 minutes on "VARNEY & COMPANY". Thank you, Stuart. "VARNEY & COMPANY" begins top of the hour, 9:00 a.m. right after MORNINGS WITH MARIA. We will take a break then all about father's day, teeing up the perfect present for dad this father's day. Taking a look at best gifts for golf lovers. But first, a message from a pro at the U.S. Open.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

JORDAN SPEITH, U.S. OPEN WINNER: Hey, Dad. I just wanted to drop a note saying that you mean the world to me. You are my biggest role model, somebody I look up to for everything especially off the course. I don't look up to you much on the course but I owe a lot to you. You have been a tremendous father to me, my brother, and my sister, and a tremendous husband to mom.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

SPEITH: I feel very lucky that I have the dad. He is a tremendous role model.

JASON DAY, GOLFER: Enjoy the moment with your loved ones. Enjoy the moment with your kids. Enjoy the moment with your wife.

DUSTIN JOHNSON, DEFENDING U.S. OPEN CHAMPION: It's a special day, so a lot of times ends on Sunday at the U.S. Open so hopefully, I get to hold that trophy on father's day. It would it be nice.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BARTIROMO: It sure would be. We are live from beautiful Erin Hills this morning in Wisconsin. We are at the 117th U.S. Open, and you just heard top tour golfer share why Father's Day this Sunday is so important to them. The holiday rakes major bucks for retailers. Americans are expected to spend a record high $15.5 billion this year, on Father's Day gifts. I want to bring in CEO and President of the PGA Tour Superstore, Dick Sullivan is with us. Dick, it's great to see you. Thanks so much for joining us.

DICK SULLIVAN, PGA TOUR SUPERSTORE PRESIDENT: Thanks, Maria. Great to be here. I wish I was with you, though. It looks beautiful out there.

BARTIROMO: We wish you were. It is gorgeous here, of course, the U.S. Open is traditionally held during the week of Father's Day. Tell us how events are driving sales at your superstore.

SULLIVAN: This is a huge week for us actually the biggest week of the year. Our number one week, only I think Christmas is number two, so we are having a great season. Actually seven and the last eight months, we had double-digit comp store increases which are significant in brick-and-mortar retail world. And our online has tripled those. This is a huge week for us. We got a lot of great gifts, this weekend will be -- this week will break a record for our company. This will be the biggest week as I said, of the year.

BARTIROMO: In fact, you've got great products right here with us. We're going to help out last-minute shoppers' check out some of the products that we have on set. Get your take on this. First, we've got a Callaway GBD Epic Driver.

SULLIVAN: This is the newest, hottest driver in the market. It just came out January, and it's got new technology they call jailbreak technology, got titanium in front of the club face, clearly the number one driver. A great gift for dad. We have many of them in our stores so people should come to our stores and buy them this weekend.

BARTIROMO: Tell us about your range finders. What is the Bushnell technology offering?

SULLIVAN: It's unbelievable these days. You can shoot them, and shoot handle will vibrate. It's all about distance and accuracy. They're so much better than in the past.

BARTIROMO: Yes Dagen, what do you got there?

DAGEN MCDOWELL, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK ANCHOR: I don't know. He can tell us the number one -

BARTIROMO: We're holding this putter here. It's got lights on it.

SULLIVAN: I can't see what you are looking at. That tailor-made part - that's the part that Rory just put into play. That is one of the hottest putters clearly. Jason Day is playing that putter; Sergio won with that putter at the Masters. It's heavy as you can see. It's more stable, allows for better role. It's a great putter and those guys playing really well with it as you see.

BARTIROMO: Jordan Spieth, one of golf's greatest moneymakers his deal with Under Armour has introduced must-have products on the course. Does the store carry anything from Under Armour?

SULLIVAN: We carry all the apparel from Under Armour. We carry shirts, pants. This is a new Spieth One shoe. And golf shoes have come a long way, not just about the look of the shoe, it is about performance. These are very, very lightweight. These are in stores at $199, another great gift for dad and these are designed by Jordan. And worked with Jordan with team Under Armour.

BARTIROMO: We came prepared. Let me ask you about these balls. Number one golf ball and then, this ball engineered to perform with every club. Tell us about these balls.

SULLIVAN: Well, the titlist is the number one gift in the store for sure. It's the number one ball played in all the tours, there is more pros playing Titlist Pro V1 than any other ball I think combined. The new ball is Taylor made TP 5.

BARTIROMO: How much are these balls?

SULLIVAN: The golf balls are 47.99 for titlist Pro V, Taylor made ball is a new ball. Actually, Justin Rose hit it. He's getting more height but getting the same distance so the ball is landing on the green.

BARTIROMO: Amazing. Dick Sullivan, thank you. Don't miss our live coverage of the U.S. Open on Fox Sports Go, Fox Sports One, back in a minute.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

BARTIROMO: That will do it for us. Someone is going to be walking home with this beauty, soon. Have a great weekend, everybody. Here is "VARNEY & COMPANY" and Stuart. Stu, take it away.

END

Document.Content:
urn:contentItem:5VWM-6151-DY0W-4108-00000-00ISIS Leader Killed - RPT; A Show of Unity; Immigration Crackdown; Fiat Chrysler Recall; Ridiculed at Starbucks; Snap Falls to IPO Price;2017-06-16T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:03:11ZLexisNexisISIS Leader Killed - RPT; A Show of Unity; Immigration Crackdown; FiatChrysler Recall; Ridiculed at Starbucks; Snap Falls to IPO Price;LanhamFULL TEXT

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: Live from the U.S. Open in Erin Hills Golf Course in Wisconsin, here's Maria Bartiromo with the special edition of "Mornings with Maria."

MARIA BARTIROMO, FBN HOST: Good Friday morning, everybody, thanks so much for joining us on a glorious Friday morning. I'm Maria Bartiromo, and it is Friday June 16th. Your top stories right now 6:00 A.M. on the East Coast.

Breaking news this morning. The Leader of ISIS reportedly killed. The Associated Press reporting Russia is claiming that it killed Abu Bakr al- Baghdadi in an airstrike in Syria. At this point, the U.S. military cannot confirm the news but we are watching what's coming out of Russia this morning. What it means for the war on terror coming up this morning.

A show of unity yesterday at the congressional baseball game last night, both teams coming together for a prayer for their colleague Congressman Steve Scalise ahead of the first pitch.

And President Trump praise lawmakers in the video message right before.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

DONALD TRUMP, PRESIDENT OF THE UNITED STATES: by playing tonight, you are showing the world that we will not be intimidated by threats, acts of violence or assaults on our democracy. The game will go on.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BARTIROMO: But the unity was short-lived unfortunately. House minority leader Nancy Pelosi already back at it attacking republicans blaming them for the nastiness in politics, what she said, coming up.

Plus, two escaped prisoners back in custody this morning thanks to hero homeowner. He held the two men at gunpoint until authorities arrived.

A massive minivan recall to report. FiatChrysler pulling vehicles off of the road over airbag concerns. We've got the details coming up.

And Snap shares under pressure, the stocks gliding. The lowest IPO price for the first time since going public. Why investors are getting real cautious on Snapchat's parent company Snap. That's coming up.

Plus, a President Trump supporter targeted at Starbucks. The company forced to apologize after a barista handed her cup that read "build a wall" instead of her name.

Futures indicating the markets to open this way. Take a look at where we stand with three and a half hours before opening bell. The Dow industrials expect to open higher this morning. They got the firmer tone. Dow Industrial up 25. NASDAQ up six, S&P 500 up as well.

In Europe, stocks are higher as well. Take a look at the Eurozone indices this morning. And we see gains across the board. The FTSE 100 in London up two-thirds of one percent. And the CAC quarante up three quarters of one percent.

In Asia overnight, markets were mixed at the close. The Asian markets, as you see. Nikkei average in Japan up half a percent. Hang Seng also higher. Although the Shanghai Composite in China was lower.

All those stories coming up this morning. And joining me right now from Erin Hills at the U.S. Open, Fox Business Network's Dagen McDowell, BGC partner, senior strategist and Fox News Contributor, Steve Cortes. Great to see you.

DAGEN MCDOWELL, FBN HOST: Good morning.

STEVE CORTES, FOX NEWS CONTRIBUTOR: Good morning.

BARTIROMO: Beautiful morning here at Erin Hills.

MCDOWELL: And the viewers get to see it but it's impossible to capture even over TV or in word as the suns comes up here. How gorgeous it is.

BARTIROMO: Absolutely beautiful. They were just mowing the lawn, getting ready for tee off in about an hour and a half.

MCDOWELL: It speaks to the kind of hospitality and the warmth and beauty that we've experienced here.

CORTES: It's called welcome to the Midwest.

BARTIROMO: Thank you.

MCDOWELL: I like how you're the self-appointed ambassador and you're from Illinois.

If Rickie Fowler wants to arrive in his pantaloons or whatever you want to call them, that's the one. If you wanted to arrive looking like that, I'd be cheering him on.

BARTIROMO: That's true. You know Stu, I have taken golf lessons just so you know. I took lessons with best of the best. I have a shot to show you, Stuart. I don't want to get you jealous or anything but Hank Haney gave me golf tips. Hank Haney of course, Tiger Woods coach. He was showing me how to putt. Quite exciting.

VARNEY: So Maria, without too far on the -

BARTIROMO: I'm not actually a neophyte in golf as you say.

VARNEY: I am not done yet, Maria. Hold on. Don't cut my segment short here.

BARTIROMO: I'm not good. I never said I was good, Stuart. OK? I just -- I got lessons and then never played again.

VARNEY: I will let you into a secret of mine. I have only played once and played nine holes only at the South Hampton Princess in Bermuda. You know what my score was for nine holes? 118. So I quit playing, I caddied and I watched all the time.

BARTIROMO: Good move.

VARNEY: Yes. I think so.

BARTIROMO: Stuart, happy father's day my friend.

VARNEY: Thank you very much indeed, Maria. And the same to all of you and your staff right there.

BARTIROMO: We will see you 10 minutes on "VARNEY & COMPANY". Thank you, Stuart. "VARNEY & COMPANY" begins top of the hour, 9:00 a.m. right after MORNINGS WITH MARIA. We will take a break then all about father's day, teeing up the perfect present for dad this father's day. Taking a look at best gifts for golf lovers. But first, a message from a pro at the U.S. Open.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

JORDAN SPEITH, U.S. OPEN WINNER: Hey, Dad. I just wanted to drop a note saying that you mean the world to me. You are my biggest role model, somebody I look up to for everything especially off the course. I don't look up to you much on the course but I owe a lot to you. You have been a tremendous father to me, my brother, and my sister, and a tremendous husband to mom.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

SPEITH: I feel very lucky that I have the dad. He is a tremendous role model.

JASON DAY, GOLFER: Enjoy the moment with your loved ones. Enjoy the moment with your kids. Enjoy the moment with your wife.

DUSTIN JOHNSON, DEFENDING U.S. OPEN CHAMPION: It's a special day, so a lot of times ends on Sunday at the U.S. Open so hopefully, I get to hold that trophy on father's day. It would it be nice.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BARTIROMO: It sure would be. We are live from beautiful Erin Hills this morning in Wisconsin. We are at the 117th U.S. Open, and you just heard top tour golfer share why Father's Day this Sunday is so important to them. The holiday rakes major bucks for retailers. Americans are expected to spend a record high $15.5 billion this year, on Father's Day gifts. I want to bring in CEO and President of the PGA Tour Superstore, Dick Sullivan is with us. Dick, it's great to see you. Thanks so much for joining us.

DICK SULLIVAN, PGA TOUR SUPERSTORE PRESIDENT: Thanks, Maria. Great to be here. I wish I was with you, though. It looks beautiful out there.

BARTIROMO: We wish you were. It is gorgeous here, of course, the U.S. Open is traditionally held during the week of Father's Day. Tell us how events are driving sales at your superstore.

SULLIVAN: This is a huge week for us actually the biggest week of the year. Our number one week, only I think Christmas is number two, so we are having a great season. Actually seven and the last eight months, we had double-digit comp store increases which are significant in brick-and-mortar retail world. And our online has tripled those. This is a huge week for us. We got a lot of great gifts, this weekend will be -- this week will break a record for our company. This will be the biggest week as I said, of the year.

BARTIROMO: In fact, you've got great products right here with us. We're going to help out last-minute shoppers' check out some of the products that we have on set. Get your take on this. First, we've got a Callaway GBD Epic Driver.

SULLIVAN: This is the newest, hottest driver in the market. It just came out January, and it's got new technology they call jailbreak technology, got titanium in front of the club face, clearly the number one driver. A great gift for dad. We have many of them in our stores so people should come to our stores and buy them this weekend.

BARTIROMO: Tell us about your range finders. What is the Bushnell technology offering?

SULLIVAN: It's unbelievable these days. You can shoot them, and shoot handle will vibrate. It's all about distance and accuracy. They're so much better than in the past.

BARTIROMO: Yes Dagen, what do you got there?

DAGEN MCDOWELL, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK ANCHOR: I don't know. He can tell us the number one -

BARTIROMO: We're holding this putter here. It's got lights on it.

SULLIVAN: I can't see what you are looking at. That tailor-made part - that's the part that Rory just put into play. That is one of the hottest putters clearly. Jason Day is playing that putter; Sergio won with that putter at the Masters. It's heavy as you can see. It's more stable, allows for better role. It's a great putter and those guys playing really well with it as you see.

BARTIROMO: Jordan Spieth, one of golf's greatest moneymakers his deal with Under Armour has introduced must-have products on the course. Does the store carry anything from Under Armour?

SULLIVAN: We carry all the apparel from Under Armour. We carry shirts, pants. This is a new Spieth One shoe. And golf shoes have come a long way, not just about the look of the shoe, it is about performance. These are very, very lightweight. These are in stores at $199, another great gift for dad and these are designed by Jordan. And worked with Jordan with team Under Armour.

BARTIROMO: We came prepared. Let me ask you about these balls. Number one golf ball and then, this ball engineered to perform with every club. Tell us about these balls.

SULLIVAN: Well, the titlist is the number one gift in the store for sure. It's the number one ball played in all the tours, there is more pros playing Titlist Pro V1 than any other ball I think combined. The new ball is Taylor made TP 5.

BARTIROMO: How much are these balls?

SULLIVAN: The golf balls are 47.99 for titlist Pro V, Taylor made ball is a new ball. Actually, Justin Rose hit it. He's getting more height but getting the same distance so the ball is landing on the green.

BARTIROMO: Amazing. Dick Sullivan, thank you. Don't miss our live coverage of the U.S. Open on Fox Sports Go, Fox Sports One, back in a minute.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

BARTIROMO: That will do it for us. Someone is going to be walking home with this beauty, soon. Have a great weekend, everybody. Here is "VARNEY & COMPANY" and Stuart. Stu, take it away.

END

urn:contentItem:5SYF-6VV1-DXY4-X2C4-00000-00Is it a Bear in Bull's Clothing? Invest to Prepare for Either Case2018-08-04T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:03:11ZLexisNexisSection BColumn 0Business/Financial DeskPg. 3WEALTH MATTERSIs it a Bear in Bull's Clothing? Invest to Prepare for Either CaseBy PAUL SULLIVAN

When it comes to how the latest economic data could have an impact on investors, two opposite interpretations emerge.

Growth of 4.1 percent in the second quarter is a sign of a buoyant economy set to keep growing for years to come, continuing a nearly decade-long expansion since the financial crisis in 2008.

Or growth of 4.1 percent in the second quarter is a short-term blip brought about by tax cuts that gave people a little extra money in their paycheck but is unsustainable in the face of mounting federal debt, higher tariffs and the prospect of a trade war that could hurt large portions of the United States economy.

On Friday, the Labor Department released the jobs report for July, showing the economy added 157,000 jobs, fewer than the expected gain of 190,000. The jobless rate dropped to 3.9 percent, suggesting slack in the labor market, but wages are growing slowly.

Your takeaway depends on your overall view of the country and the economy.

''In 23 years of doing this, I cannot really remember a time when a statistic comes out and you hear such diametrically opposed interpretations of it,'' said Andrew Crowell, vice chairman of wealth management at D. A. Davidson & Company, which manages $48.2 billion. ''There is no gray zone. It's only black and white, which makes it an interesting time to be an investor.''

Who's correct on the data will not be known until the economic impact is felt, which could take months or even years. But for investors, any plan based on waiting or wishing is not ideal.

After all, even before President Trump began to shake up economic norms, with his criticism of the Federal Reserve, threats of tariffs and nonchalance about government debt, investors were skeptical of the economic expansion, which has run, with a few minor dips, from March 2009 to the present.

A wait-and-see approach on investing can be costly, but moving too quickly at this stage could be ruinous if the market goes into a correction. Advisers to some of the country's wealthiest people say to keep investing but to do it wisely.

Here are four tips for investors in a time of caution:

Diversify Your Portfolio

Mr. Trump has made many comments that in a different time would have caused the economy to tank. Military threats against North Korea and Iran, tariffs against the United States' largest trading partners, all manner of statements about Russia -- none of them has caused a market correction.

Instead, the opposite has happened this year, as investors find opportunities in market fluctuations. ''We've seen cash come in to buy on the dips,'' Mr. Crowell said.

And for a seemingly sound reason: Companies continue to grow. The Republican tax cut that was enacted last year and a rollback of financial regulations have helped, but so have strong earnings that have outpaced price increases.

''The stimulative measures have bolstered confidence that growth and the economy is going to be strong over the next couple of years,'' Mr. Crowell said.

Advisers agree that the recovery has been running for some time and is near the point where bull markets typically begin to falter. But that does not mean the run will end this year or next or even the year after that.

''Consumer wealth is at all-time highs when you factor in home prices and the stock market,'' said Henry B. Smith, co-chief investment officer at the Haverford Trust Company, which manages $8 billion. ''One of the lacking ingredients throughout this has been business investment, and that is starting to pick up.''

Mr. Smith is advising his clients to have the maximum exposure to equities that they can stomach. But he is also telling them to think more broadly about equities.

Investors often overlook the moderating role of value stocks, which are steady, dividend-paying stocks that can help weather various economic storms. Instead, they often pursue the higher returns of growth stocks, which are expected to grow at an above-average rate.

Mr. Smith said investors should think about trimming back investments in manufacturing, technology and financial services to increase holdings of consumer staples, health care, telecommunication and utility stocks, the basics of value investing.

He cited last week's sudden drop in the value of Facebook as reason to broaden your view of equities. ''Last week was a good reminder that stocks that go up sharply can also come down sharply,'' he said.

Be Aware of Opportunities

Many investors seem willing to forget that the returns of the past decade have been strong and that replicating them going forward may be difficult. In other words, stay invested in riskier assets while they continue to run, because selling them too early could hurt your portfolio.

''When we look at demographics and economic projections, there isn't going to be as much population growth and consumption,'' said Anthony Roth, chief investment officer at Wilmington Trust. ''Most of the world has a population moving to slower consumption as they age. While this economic cycle is continuing, the risk of missing out is even greater.''

Mr. Roth pointed to the reaction over the flattening of the yield curve, which tracks the difference between the interest rate on short-term bonds and long-term bonds. He said talk about the yield curve inverting -- which means long-term borrowing costs become less than those in the short term -- was premature.

''The strongest period of the market cycle is from the time of yield curve inversion to the peak of the equity market, which is usually nine to 12 months after that,'' Mr. Roth said. ''We haven't even gotten to the inversion yet, which would suggest there's significant opportunity right now.''

Yet investors need to pay attention. ''The alarm is when the yield curve inverts,'' he said. ''It's a predictor of both recessions and returns in the market.''

Actively monitoring economic data and what it presages is a smart strategy.

Pick Recession-Resistant Stocks

Most analysts believe that Mr. Trump is bluffing on tariffs and that they are being used as a negotiating tool. This comes from the school of thought that favors what the president does over what he says.

For instance, after saying so many harsh things about European trading partners, Mr. Trump embraced Jean-Claude Juncker, president of the European Commission, just last week.

''The worst case is, Trump just gets in a fight with China, Europe and everyone else and we see an escalation of tariffs that slows world trade and has a significant impact on the U.S. economic cycle, increases inflationary pressures and ultimately reduces output,'' said John S. Osterweis, chairman and chief investment officer of Osterweis Capital Management, which manages about $7 billion.

That would be crushing, but it is not the only possible outcome.

''The flip side is, Trump really is a master negotiator and what he's doing is trying to move away from multilateral trade agreements to bilateral agreements,'' Mr. Osterweis said. That may produce better trade deals, he said.

Lacking any idea as to which outcome to expect, Mr. Osterweis has been encouraging clients to invest in companies whose outlooks are less dependent on the economy or a particular industry, he said.

''You could think of a Google, where people's search habits aren't going to change dramatically if there's a recession and there's already an inexorable migration of ad dollars to that company,'' he said. ''You could look at a drug company with a blockbuster drug coming through the pipeline or a Disney, where they have the next unbelievably popular movie coming out.''

The opposite would be manufacturing companies like automakers that stockpile inventory and could struggle to sell it in a recession. Still, some combination of different types of companies is the more prudent bet.

Consider the Tax Implications

Facebook's loss of nearly 20 percent of its value in one day was substantial. But Mr. Crowell said it should not cause people to run from the Big Tech stocks like Alphabet, Amazon, Facebook and Netflix.

What it should do is get people thinking about the need to examine their portfolios. ''It's prudent to be mindful that those four names don't define a diversified portfolio,'' he said.

Another reason not to sell off stocks that have appreciated greatly is taxes. People who have held those stocks for a long time have watched them run up in value, which means they are going to owe a lot of money in taxes when they sell them.

Todd Morgan, chairman of Bel Air Investment Advisors, which manages about $8 billion for high-net-worth families, said he shows clients how much the stock of a fundamentally strong company would have to fall before selling it made sense.

''People don't look at the after-tax returns,'' Mr. Morgan said. ''I've had several calls about tech stocks the past few days, all asking, 'Should we stay in or get out?'''

If an investor thinks a company is going to drop below what would be owed in capital gains taxes, then it is time to get out.

Investors need to keep paying attention to company fundamentals and economic indicators focused on inflation and wages. If either of those runs too high, the Federal Reserve is likely to raise interest rates, which could bring the equity party to an end.

Since neither is happening now, the best advice is to stay invested and stay alert.

PHOTOS: Above, Wando Terminal in Charleston, S.C.President Trump, left, welcomed Jean-Claude Juncker, the president of the European Commission, despite speaking harshly of trading partners in Europe. (PHOTOGRAPHS BY DUSTIN CHAMBERS FOR THE NEW YORK TIMES

DOUG MILLS/THE NEW YORK TIMES)
